Award.AwardTitle: Early Village Social Dynamics: Prehistoric Settlement Nucleation on the Great Hungarian Plain

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
With National Science Foundation support Drs. William Parkinson and Dr. Richard Yerkes will work with an international team of colleagues to conduct three seasons of multi-disciplinary field research in southeastern Hungary. The team brings together U.S., Hungarian, Greek, and Serbian specialists in archaeology, paleo-botany, archaeo-zoology, geophysics, soil chemistry, and geomorphology to examine the development of pre-urban settlements in the Körös Region of the Great Hungarian Plain within the Carpathian Basin in Central Europe.

Specifically, the team will examine the process of settlement nucleation and population aggregation as revealed in the archaeology of agricultural villages during the Middle and Late Neolithic (5,300-4,700 cal BC). The project examines dramatic changes in socio-economic organization and settlement patterns that occurred nearly a thousand years after farming was established in the Carpathian Basin. These changes include natural and cultural processes that led to the establishment of compact, nucleated, fortified, villages that grew by accretion into 'tells' (artificial mounds of stratified occupations that spanned several centuries and consist of layers of leveled wattle-and-daub structures, filled-in features, and burials). This multi-disciplinary research project at several Neolithic sites in the Sebes-Körös region, Hungary will test models of settlement aggregation and nucleation that can be used to explore similar social processes elsewhere in the world.

The main research objective is to test explanatory models for the emergence of nucleated agricultural villages that emphasize different causal factors (e.g., environmental changes, new animal husbandry practices, intensification of ritual and warfare, demographic transformation). The multi-disciplinary, international team will conduct systematic investigations at two tells and contemporary "flat" (non-tell) sites in the Sebes-Körös Region of Hungary. A geomorphological and soil coring program aimed at reconstructing the mid-Holocene hydrology of the region will also be conducted. Most data recovery and analysis will occur in Hungary, with only some samples for destructive analysis being brought back to the U.S. Data entry and artifact processing, cleaning, and sorting will occur daily at the research facility in Vésztõ.

This study of nucleation in ancient village societies contributes to a broader anthropological understanding of the natural and cultural processes that laid the foundation for many other social changes, including the emergence of urbanization, territorialism and the development of economic and political complexity. By assessing independent lines of evidence, it will be possible to demonstrate how environmental, ecological, and social factors resulted in settlement nucleation, and eventually the development of large urban centers. Investigations of this long-term process on the Great Hungarian Plain will contribute to a general understanding of the social and structural dynamics within autonomous village or tribal societies that pushed and pulled them eventually toward social stratification, hierarchical organization, and urbanization.

The proposed research will contribute to anthropological knowledge and social theory, advance international collaboration between American and East European scholars, and make datasets and research results widely available in public lectures, scientific journals, websites, and a monograph. It will increase technological and scientific understanding of the human past, and demonstrate how current social problems may have originated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Long before there were cities in Mesopotamia and Egypt, Hungarian village farmers had one of the most sophisticated and technologically advanced societies in the world. They brought their crops, and livestock up through the Balkans 6500 years ago, and some think they created a new social order where hereditary chiefs now led the formerly egalitarian tribes. However, the artificial mounds or tells that the chiefs lived on appeared nearly a millennium after the farmers arrived. Tells were inhabited from 5200 to 4500 BC. It is clear that agriculture was not the cause, or the result, of population nucleation at tells. If it wasn’t farming, then what transformed the Neolithic tribes and drew farmers to the tells? Was it climate and environmental change, new rituals, warfare, or increasing group size? Did social ranking and hereditary inequality develop during this transformation?

With generous support from NSF, the Körös Regional Archaeological Project tried to answer these questions (Fig. 1). We investigated two Neolithic tell-centered villages on the banks of the Sebes-Körös River in Hungary: Szeghalom-Kovácshalom and Vészt?-Mágor (Fig. 2). Both tells lie along the same river channel, only five miles apart, but each had a different settlement layout (Figure 3). There was no “standard” village plan.

At Szeghalom-Kovácshalom (SzK50), a large village covering over 220 acres with 160 wattle-and-daub longhouses surrounded a small 11.5’ high, 1.2 acre tell. Longhouse clusters formed “neighborhoods” on river terraces near that tell, while “farmsteads” with several longhouses were located further out. Isolated longhouses across the river were at lower elevations (Figure 4). There were larger “men’s houses” or clan leader’s residences in each neighborhood (Figure 5). The orientation of most longhouses is the same. Radiocarbon dates suggest the settlement expanded rapidly around 4800 BC. If the longhouses are contemporary, 550-800 people may have lived in the SzK50 village. Longhouses on lower landforms subject to flooding may have only been inhabited during dry periods. Dates from Szeghalom-Kovácshalom tell showed that it also grew rapidly. There are hints of elite residences, elite burials, and ritual areas on that tell. Only one men’s or clan leader’s house (S81) was excavated, and its size and contents were different than smaller excavated longhouses. Szeghalom-Kovácshalom seems to be a group-oriented village where chiefs lived on the tell, but shared power with clan leaders in the surrounding neighborhoods.

Vészt?-Mágor tell is 30’ high and covers 10.5 acres (five times larger than Szeghalom-Kovácshalom tell), but there is no surrounding village (Figure 3). There is more evidence for hereditary inequality at Vészt?-Mágor, including grave goods buried with children (suggesting they inherited their status), fortifications enclosing the tell, and ritual spaces with figurines and cult objects. Some adults and children were buried in wooden coffins. Vészt?-Mágor may have developed as a village where one tribal chief gained more power. There was little difference in plant remains found in houses on and off the tells. However, more game was consumed by tell residents. Nearly 1/3 of the mammal remains at Vészt?-Mágor were wild boar, red deer, and wild cattle. In ethnographic descriptions of rank societies, increased game consumption by chiefs was noted. However, a study of carbon and nitrogen levels in human bone (which measures plant and meat consumption) did not find any correlation between diet and number and type of grave goods. Diets of Neolithic chiefs may not have been that different from other tribe members.
